answers.answer: Not always. The biggest concern is that the baby will be too big to come out. Your doc should give you a lot more info at your appt today
I hope she does!! Sometimes I think she forgets this is my first pregnancy :/ .

I had gestational diabetes with my 3rd pregnancy, my son was not huge (7lbs 13oz) he was 4 days early and came on his own. Having GD was not horrible, I thought so at first and thought I did something wrong, but honestly it ended up being just an adjustment. Better portion control, eating healthier and I didnt gain as much as I did with my first 2. Now I'm on my 4th and last pregnancy and no GD this time (38wks6days). You will be ok;-) Best Wishes!!

Thank you that means alot!!!! When I found out I cried! I know I have to alot to change and its all for her and will be totally worth it I'm just scared on how to change 25 years of eating habits. I feel like at 38 weeks she's safer out then in but I want her to come on her own I don't want more stress on her if that makes sense.
I had gestation diabetes and went past my due date and my DD was only 8lb 2oz because I controlled my diet and ate healthy after finding out

It makes complete sense;-) changing eating habits is hard, I know, and paying attention to all the carbs is frustrating too. I actually learned a lot though;-) but u r right, it's what's best for your baby. My suggestion is using measuring cups to help and finding all the freebies you like (I think carrots was one, can't remember) and snacking on those things so u don't feel like your starving. If u have any questions don't hesitate to inbox me;-) I also ended up needing to give myself insulin shots, but it was all worth it in the end;-) take care!!

question: Friday night I found out I failed my 3 hour glucose test. I go Tuesday to find out my next steps. My sister had gestational diabetes and had to be induced at 38 weeks. I was just wondering if I would have to be also?
title: do they really?
